elements.content: A rare uninodal 9-connected metal−organic framework (Zn3(TAA)3(H2O)3·(1,4-dioxane) (MOF 1) (TAA = 1-H-tetrazole-5-acetate) was synthesized, structurally characterized, and topologically rationalized as a vnd net, exhibiting permanent porosity, and solvent-dependent luminescence properties.
elements.clean_text: A rare uninodal 9-connected metal-organic framework (Zn3(TAA)3(H2O)3⋅(1,4-dioxane) (MOF 1) (TAA = 1-H-tetrazole-5-acetate) was synthesized, structurally characterized, and topologically rationalized as a vnd net, exhibiting permanent porosity, and solvent-dependent luminescence properties.

elements.content: A rare uninodal 9-connected metal−organic framework (Zn3(TAA)3(H2O)3·(1,4-dioxane) (MOF 1) (TAA = 1-H-tetrazole-5-acetate) was synthesized, structurally characterized, and topologically rationalized as a vnd net, exhibiting permanent porosity and solvent-dependent luminescence properties.
elements.clean_text: A rare uninodal 9-connected metal-organic framework (Zn3(TAA)3(H2O)3⋅(1,4-dioxane) (MOF 1) (TAA = 1-H-tetrazole-5-acetate) was synthesized, structurally characterized, and topologically rationalized as a vnd net, exhibiting permanent porosity and solvent-dependent luminescence properties.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have been of great interest over the past two decades because of their intriguing structures and diverse functionalities. The pioneering works by Wells and O’Keeffe et al. on the analyses and classification of nets have provided the basic principles to rationalize the topologies of MOFs. Among the great number of topologically rationalized MOFs, the majority of them are low-connected (3-8) networks, while high-connected (>8) MOFs are very rare. This is partly because of the restricted binding sites of single metal ions for the organic bridging linkers, particularly when such linkers are very bulky. One effective strategy for the construction of high-connected MOFs is to employ metal clusters instead of single metal ions, which certainly provides much more binding sites to assemble high-connected MOFs. In our pursuit of novel functional porous MOFs, we realized an unprecedented three-dimensional (3D) nine-connected network of a vnd net in two porous MOFs Zn3(TAA)3(H2O)3·(1,4-dioxane) (MOF 1) and Zn3(TAA)3(H2O)3·(DMSO) (MOF 2) (TAA = 1-H-tetrazole-5-acetate). Herein we report the synthesis, structures, and properties of these two new porous MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been of great interest over the past two decades because of their intriguing structures and diverse functionalities. The pioneering works by Wells and O'Keeffe et al. on the analyses and classification of nets have provided the basic principles to rationalize the topologies of MOFs. Among the great number of topologically rationalized MOFs, the majority of them are low-connected (3-8) networks, while high-connected (>8) MOFs are very rare. This is partly because of the restricted binding sites of single metal ions for the organic bridging linkers, particularly when such linkers are very bulky. One effective strategy for the construction of high-connected MOFs is to employ metal clusters instead of single metal ions, which certainly provides much more binding sites to assemble high-connected MOFs. In our pursuit of novel functional porous MOFs, we realized an unprecedented three-dimensional (3D) nine-connected network of a vnd net in two porous MOFs Zn3(TAA)3(H2O)3⋅(1,4-dioxane) (MOF 1) and Zn3(TAA)3(H2O)3⋅(DMSO) (MOF 2) (TAA = 1-H-tetrazole-5-acetate). Herein we report the synthesis, structures, and properties of these two new porous MOFs.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were used as received from commercial suppliers without further purification. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 3 °C/min using a Shimadzu TGA-50 thermogravimetric analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a RIGAMU D/MAX 2550/PC X diffractometer with CuKα radiation.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents and solvents were used as received from commercial suppliers without further purification. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 3 °C/min using a Shimadzu TGA-50 thermogravimetric analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a RIGAMU D/MAX 2550/PC X diffractometer with CuKα radiation.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0900 g, 0.3 mmol) and HTAA (0.0130 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (5 mL), ethanol (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL) in a 23 mL vial, and then heated at 65 °C for 48 h to form colorless crystals (0.012 mg, 51%). The crystals were washed with ethanol.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOF 1 

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0900 g, 0.3 mmol) and HTAA (0.0130 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (5 mL), ethanol (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL) in a 23 mL vial, and then heated at 65 °C for 48 h to form colorless crystals (0.012 mg, 51%). The crystals were washed with ethanol.

elements.content:
MOF 2 was prepared under conditions similar to those of MOF 1 with DMSO (5 mL) instead of 1,4-dioxane to form colorless crystals (0.016 mg, 68%). The crystals were washed with ethanol.

X-ray Crystallographic Study

The intensity data sets of MOF 1 was collected on a Rigaku Saturn724 diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using an ω-scan technique at 293 K. The data set was reduced by CrystalClear and CrystalStructure programs. The intensity data set of MOF 2 was collected on a Bruker X8 APEX II diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) using a φ−ω-scan technique at 90 K. The data set was reduced by Bruker SAINT+ programs. The structures were solved by direct methods using the Siemens SHELXTL-97 package of crystallographic software. The difference Fourier maps based on these atomic positions yield the other non-H atoms. The structures were refined using full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2. The H atoms were allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms and included in the structure factor calculations with assigned isotropic thermal parameters, except for the H atoms of the disordered S atoms and the C and O atoms connected with the disordered S atoms. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for MOF 1 and 2 are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
MOF 2 was prepared under conditions similar to those of MOF 1 with DMSO (5 mL) instead of 1,4-dioxane to form colorless crystals (0.016 mg, 68%). The crystals were washed with ethanol.

X-ray Crystallographic Study

The intensity data sets of MOF 1 was collected on a Rigaku Saturn724 diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using an ω-scan technique at 293 K. The data set was reduced by CrystalClear and CrystalStructure programs. The intensity data set of MOF 2 was collected on a Bruker X8 APEX II diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) using a φ-ω-scan technique at 90 K. The data set was reduced by Bruker SAINT+ programs. The structures were solved by direct methods using the Siemens SHELXTL-97 package of crystallographic software. The difference Fourier maps based on these atomic positions yield the other non-H atoms. The structures were refined using full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2. The H atoms were allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms and included in the structure factor calculations with assigned isotropic thermal parameters, except for the H atoms of the disordered S atoms and the C and O atoms connected with the disordered S atoms. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for MOF 1 and 2 are summarized in Table .

A Coulter Omnisorp 100cx analyzer was used to measure vapor adsorption isotherms. The fresh sample was heated at 150 °C for 2 h under high vacuum before the adsorption studies.

Fluorescence Measurements

The fluorescence properties of MOF 1 and solvent exchanged MOF 1 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. A fresh sample (30 mg) of MOF 1 was activated at 70 °C for 24 h under a vacuum and then immersed into an organic solvent (20 mL) to form solvent exchanged MOF 1 which was collected by filtration and drying for 24 h at 20 °C. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded by a Hitachi F4500 fluorescence spectrometer. The photomultiplier tube voltage was 700 V and the scan speed was 240 nm/min. And the slit widths were respectively 1.0 and 2.5 nm for excitation and emission spectra.
elements.clean_text:
Methanol Sorption Isotherm

A Coulter Omnisorp 100cx analyzer was used to measure vapor adsorption isotherms. The fresh sample was heated at 150 °C for 2 h under high vacuum before the adsorption studies.

Fluorescence Measurements

The fluorescence properties of MOF 1 and solvent exchanged MOF 1 were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. A fresh sample (30 mg) of MOF 1 was activated at 70 °C for 24 h under a vacuum and then immersed into an organic solvent (20 mL) to form solvent exchanged MOF 1 which was collected by filtration and drying for 24 h at 20 °C. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded by a Hitachi F4500 fluorescence spectrometer. The photomultiplier tube voltage was 700 V and the scan speed was 240 nm/min. And the slit widths were respectively 1.0 and 2.5 nm for excitation and emission spectra.

elements.content: MOF 1 and 2 can be readily synthesized by the solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2 with HTAA in a mixture solvent 1,4-dioxane/ethanol/H2O and DMSO/ethanol/H2O, respectively, as highly crystalline solids.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 MOF 1 and 2 can be readily synthesized by the solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2 with HTAA in a mixture solvent 1,4-dioxane/ethanol/H2O and DMSO/ethanol/H2O, respectively, as highly crystalline solids.

elements.content: These two MOFs exhibit the same framework structures, and the structure of the representative MOF 1 is discussed in detail. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis revealed that MOF 1 crystallizes in the space group P21/n. There are three crystallographically unique Zn atoms coordinated with three Taa ligands (L1, L2, and L3) and two water molecules (Figure a). In comparison with the distorted [ZnN3O2] square pyramid geometry of the Zn1 atom, Zn2 and Zn3 have [ZnN3O3] and [ZnN4O2] distorted octahedral geometries. The Zn−O and Zn−N bond lengths range from 2.044(2) to 2.213(2) Å and 2.019(3) to 2.200(3) Å, respectively, which are comparable to those reported in the literature. As shown in Figure b, L1 and L2 show the same μ4-κN1: κN2: κN4, O1: κO2 coordination mode, while L3, connecting with three crystallographically independent Zn atoms, presents a μ3-κN1: κN4, O1: κO1 coordiantion mode to form a trinuclear Zn3(L3) unit. The dihedral angle between the tetrazolate ring and carboxylate group of L3 (51.7°) is larger than those of L1 (34.0°) and L2 (23.3°). Each trinuclear cluster interlinks with nine adjacent clusters to form a 3D framework by the connection of L1 and L2 ligands. In this context the structure of 1 can be described as a 3D uninodal nine-connected framework, in which the nodes are [Zn3(L3)] clusters and the L1 and L2 act as spacers (Figure a−c). The distances between the nodes range from 7.89 to 11.32 Å. The topology of the network has a Schläfli symbol of 3942057 and is identified by the code vnd in the RCSR database. Although O’Keeffe theoretically identified 29 nets of 9-connected topologies in the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) database, to the best of our knowledge, only two 9-connected MOFs with ncd and ncb nets have been realized, while our reported vnd net in MOF 1 and 2 is the first example of 9-connected MOFs with a vnd net. Herein, vnd is similar to ncd having two (3.43)(32.43)-nets () jointing with a 44 net, but a 44 net in vnd separates two offsetting (3.43)(32.43)-nets to a mixed triangles and squares part on one side and a squares part on another side (Figure d).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

These two MOFs exhibit the same framework structures, and the structure of the representative MOF 1 is discussed in detail. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis revealed that MOF 1 crystallizes in the space group P21/n. There are three crystallographically unique Zn atoms coordinated with three Taa ligands (L1, L2, and L3) and two water molecules (Figure a). In comparison with the distorted [ZnN3O2] square pyramid geometry of the Zn1 atom, Zn2 and Zn3 have [ZnN3O3] and [ZnN4O2] distorted octahedral geometries. The Zn-O and Zn-N bond lengths range from 2.044(2) to 2.213(2) Å and 2.019(3) to 2.200(3) Å, respectively, which are comparable to those reported in the literature. As shown in Figure b, L1 and L2 show the same μ4-κN1: κN2: κN4, O1: κO2 coordination mode, while L3, connecting with three crystallographically independent Zn atoms, presents a μ3-κN1: κN4, O1: κO1 coordiantion mode to form a trinuclear Zn3(L3) unit. The dihedral angle between the tetrazolate ring and carboxylate group of L3 (51.7°) is larger than those of L1 (34.0°) and L2 (23.3°). Each trinuclear cluster interlinks with nine adjacent clusters to form a 3D framework by the connection of L1 and L2 ligands. In this context the structure of 1 can be described as a 3D uninodal nine-connected framework, in which the nodes are [Zn3(L3)] clusters and the L1 and L2 act as spacers (Figure a-c). The distances between the nodes range from 7.89 to 11.32 Å. The topology of the network has a Schläfli symbol of 3942057 and is identified by the code vnd in the RCSR database. Although O'Keeffe theoretically identified 29 nets of 9-connected topologies in the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) database, to the best of our knowledge, only two 9-connected MOFs with ncd and ncb nets have been realized, while our reported vnd net in MOF 1 and 2 is the first example of 9-connected MOFs with a vnd net. Herein, vnd is similar to ncd having two (3.43)(32.43)-nets () jointing with a 44 net, but a 44 net in vnd separates two offsetting (3.43)(32.43)-nets to a mixed triangles and squares part on one side and a squares part on another side (Figure d).

elements.content: (a) View of the trinuclear unit. Zn: dark gray; O in coordinated water molecules: red; L1: pink; L2: cyan; L3: green. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. (b) Coordination modes of three TAA ligands in MOF 1.

elements.content: MOF 1 is quite different from other high-connected MOFs with carboxylate linkers because of the bifunctional nature of TAA tetrazolate-carboxylate ligands in which TAA acts as both part of node and spacer. Another striking feature of 1 is the two achiral channels with chiral walls formed by linkages between the Zn ions and the L1 and L2. As shown in Figure a,b, Zn2 and Zn3 atoms link L1 or L2 to form left- or right-handed single-helical chains with a period of 8.86 Å running along the 21 axes. Homohanded helixes formed by ZnL1 and ZnL2 alternatively interlink to form a 2D sheets extending along the b and c axes through sharing Zn2 and Zn3 atoms. The sheets stack along the a axis and connect with each other via Zn1 atoms to form a 3D framework with two achiral channels A and B along the b direction (Figure b,c). Channel A is filled with terminal water and guest 1,4-dioxane molecules with an opening of 7.1 × 2.2 Å2 which accounts approximately 30.2% (0.183 cm3 g−1) of the whole crystal volume (698.7 Å3 out of the 2313.7 Å3 per unit cell volume) by PLATON analysis. As shown in Figure a,b, L3 connects with three Zn atoms to consolidate the chiral wall of channel A while occupying the pore space of channel B.
elements.clean_text: MOF 1 is quite different from other high-connected MOFs with carboxylate linkers because of the bifunctional nature of TAA tetrazolate-carboxylate ligands in which TAA acts as both part of node and spacer. Another striking feature of 1 is the two achiral channels with chiral walls formed by linkages between the Zn ions and the L1 and L2. As shown in Figure a,b, Zn2 and Zn3 atoms link L1 or L2 to form left- or right-handed single-helical chains with a period of 8.86 Å running along the 21 axes. Homohanded helixes formed by ZnL1 and ZnL2 alternatively interlink to form a 2D sheets extending along the b and c axes through sharing Zn2 and Zn3 atoms. The sheets stack along the a axis and connect with each other via Zn1 atoms to form a 3D framework with two achiral channels A and B along the b direction (Figure b,c). Channel A is filled with terminal water and guest 1,4-dioxane molecules with an opening of 7.1 × 2.2 Å2 which accounts approximately 30.2% (0.183 cm3 g-1) of the whole crystal volume (698.7 Å3 out of the 2313.7 Å3 per unit cell volume) by PLATON analysis. As shown in Figure a,b, L3 connects with three Zn atoms to consolidate the chiral wall of channel A while occupying the pore space of channel B.

elements.content: TG and X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were carried out to examine the thermal stability of the porous networks. TGA data indicate that 1 releases 1,4-dioxane in the temperature range of 50−250 °C, and the framework is stable up to 370 °C (). The powder XRD pattern further confirms that the framework is retained after the removal of guest molecules by thermal activation at 200 °C ().
elements.clean_text: TG and X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were carried out to examine the thermal stability of the porous networks. TGA data indicate that 1 releases 1,4-dioxane in the temperature range of 50-250 °C, and the framework is stable up to 370 °C (). The powder XRD pattern further confirms that the framework is retained after the removal of guest molecules by thermal activation at 200 °C ().

elements.content: To establish the permanent porosity, the methanol adsorption isotherm of the activated 1 was measured at room temperature (ca. 298 K). As shown in Figure , the activated MOF 1 exhibits type II adsorption behavior with respect to CH3OH. The activated MOF 1 can adsorb the maximum amount of 34 cm3 (STP)/g under the pressure P/P 0 of ca. 0.92 at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Methanol Sorption Properties of MOF 1 

To establish the permanent porosity, the methanol adsorption isotherm of the activated 1 was measured at room temperature (ca. 298 K). As shown in Figure , the activated MOF 1 exhibits type II adsorption behavior with respect to CH3OH. The activated MOF 1 can adsorb the maximum amount of 34 cm3 (STP)/g under the pressure P/P 0 of ca. 0.92 at room temperature.

elements.content: Methanol adsorption isotherm for MOF 1 at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 5  Methanol adsorption isotherm for MOF 1 at room temperature.

elements.content: Although the photoluminescence of d10 metal complexes has been widely investigated, the studies on solvent-dependent luminescence of d10-MOFs are still not well developed. As shown in Figure and , thermally activated MOF 1 exhibits a strong photoluminescent emission band at 438 nm upon photoexcitation at 373 nm, which can probably be attributed to ligand-centered π−π* excitation. To examine the potential of MOF 1 for the sensing of small molecules, activated MOF 1 samples were immersed in different solvent molecules for fluorescence investigation. As shown in Figure , the activated MOF 1 exhibits heavily solvent-dependent PL spectra. The addition of methanol and isopropanol into the activated MOF 1 led to enhanced and reduced luminescence intensity, respectively. The enhanced luminescence intensity might be attributed to the encapsulated methanol molecules which enforces the framework and thus diminishes the C−H stretching of organic linker TAA. The small pores of 7.1 × 2.2 Å2 in MOF 1 might restrict its full uptake of isopropanol, so the isopropanol included MOF 1 has a higher degree of framework flexibility, leading to reduced luminescence intensity. Such solvent-dependent luminescent properties of porous MOFs might be utilized as the novel functional sensing materials.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing Properties of MOF 1 

Although the photoluminescence of d10 metal complexes has been widely investigated, the studies on solvent-dependent luminescence of d10-MOFs are still not well developed. As shown in Figure  and , thermally activated MOF 1 exhibits a strong photoluminescent emission band at 438 nm upon photoexcitation at 373 nm, which can probably be attributed to ligand-centered π-π* excitation. To examine the potential of MOF 1 for the sensing of small molecules, activated MOF 1 samples were immersed in different solvent molecules for fluorescence investigation. As shown in Figure , the activated MOF 1 exhibits heavily solvent-dependent PL spectra. The addition of methanol and isopropanol into the activated MOF 1 led to enhanced and reduced luminescence intensity, respectively. The enhanced luminescence intensity might be attributed to the encapsulated methanol molecules which enforces the framework and thus diminishes the C-H stretching of organic linker TAA. The small pores of 7.1 × 2.2 Å2 in MOF 1 might restrict its full uptake of isopropanol, so the isopropanol included MOF 1 has a higher degree of framework flexibility, leading to reduced luminescence intensity. Such solvent-dependent luminescent properties of porous MOFs might be utilized as the novel functional sensing materials.

elements.content: Emission spectra of solid MOF 1a in different solvents when excited at 373 nm. The inset: The emission intensity at 438 nm.
elements.clean_text: 6  Emission spectra of solid MOF 1a in different solvents when excited at 373 nm. The inset: The emission intensity at 438 nm.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized two novel 3D porous MOFs with an unprecedented uninodal 9-connected topology vnd by making use of a multidentate polyazole-carboxylate linker. The permanent porosity was established by methanol vapor adsorption, while the solvent-dependent luminescent properties of MOF 1 indicate the potential of MOF 1 for the sensing of small molecules. The rich organic chemistry has provided the infinite organic bridging linkers to construct the porous MOFs and to tune their luminescence properties; it is expected that more porous MOFs of novel interesting structures and sensing functions will be emerging in the future.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized two novel 3D porous MOFs with an unprecedented uninodal 9-connected topology vnd by making use of a multidentate polyazole-carboxylate linker. The permanent porosity was established by methanol vapor adsorption, while the solvent-dependent luminescent properties of MOF 1 indicate the potential of MOF 1 for the sensing of small molecules. The rich organic chemistry has provided the infinite organic bridging linkers to construct the porous MOFs and to tune their luminescence properties; it is expected that more porous MOFs of novel interesting structures and sensing functions will be emerging in the future.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0900 g, 0.3 mmol) and HTAA (0.0130 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (5 mL), ethanol (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL) in a 23 mL vial, and then heated at 65 °C for 48 h to form colorless crystals (0.012 mg, 51%). The crystals were washed with ethanol.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOF 1 

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0900 g, 0.3 mmol) and HTAA (0.0130 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane (5 mL), ethanol (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL) in a 23 mL vial, and then heated at 65 °C for 48 h to form colorless crystals (0.012 mg, 51%). The crystals were washed with ethanol.

cln_elements.content:
TG and X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were carried out to examine the thermal stability of the porous networks. TGA data indicate that 1 releases 1,4-dioxane in the temperature range of 50−250 °C, and the framework is stable up to 370 °C (). The powder XRD pattern further confirms that the framework is retained after the removal of guest molecules by thermal activation at 200 °C ().

Methanol Sorption Properties of <bold>MOF 1</bold>

To establish the permanent porosity, the methanol adsorption isotherm of the activated 1 was measured at room temperature (ca. 298 K). As shown in Figure , the activated MOF 1 exhibits type II adsorption behavior with respect to CH3OH. The activated MOF 1 can adsorb the maximum amount of 34 cm3 (STP)/g under the pressure P/P 0 of ca. 0.92 at room temperature.
cln_elements.clean_text:
TG and X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were carried out to examine the thermal stability of the porous networks. TGA data indicate that 1 releases 1,4-dioxane in the temperature range of 50-250 °C, and the framework is stable up to 370 °C (). The powder XRD pattern further confirms that the framework is retained after the removal of guest molecules by thermal activation at 200 °C ().

Methanol Sorption Properties of MOF 1 

To establish the permanent porosity, the methanol adsorption isotherm of the activated 1 was measured at room temperature (ca. 298 K). As shown in Figure , the activated MOF 1 exhibits type II adsorption behavior with respect to CH3OH. The activated MOF 1 can adsorb the maximum amount of 34 cm3 (STP)/g under the pressure P/P 0 of ca. 0.92 at room temperature.

metadata.title: A Rare Uninodal 9-Connected Metal−Organic Framework with Permanent Porosity
